author: Simon Meechan
title: Jarrow constituency General Election 2017 - parties, candidates and the history of the seat
text:
Jarrow Town Hall (Photo: Bill Laverty) Share Get daily   Thank you for subscribing!   
If you’re due to cast your vote in the Jarrow constituency on June 8 we’ve got everything you need to know right here. 
Britain will go to the polls to elect a government and prime minister after Theresa May called a snap general election. 
We’ll be covering events on our live blog on election day, but in the meantime we’ve got the information you need before you decide which box to put your cross in. What constituency am I? 
Enter your postcode below to find out more details on your constituency. The constituency 
Traditional mining and shipbuilding area includes Jarrow, Hebburn, Boldon, Cleadon and Whitburn. The constituency is best known for the iconic Jarrow Crusade in 1936 when 207 marches walked 300 miles to London to present a petition to Parliament about the extreme levels of unemployment there. They were joined by their MP Ellen Wilkinson. Which parties and candidates are standing in Jarrow? 
Labour - Stephen Hepburn Stephen Hepburn MP 
Jarrow born Stephen Hepburn worked as assistant to former Labour MP Donald Dixon between 1979 and 1997. In 1997, Mr Hepburn took his place as Jarrow’s Labour candidate. 
The former Springfield Comprehensive School pupil and Newcastle University graduate served as South Tyneside Council’s deputy leader for seven years from 1990. A councillor since 1985, he has remained on the council while serving as an MP. 
Mr Hepburn, the son of a shipyard worker, has served on select committees for defence and Northern Ireland, and is secretary of the all-party group for football. 
Conservatives - Robin Gwynn Robin Gwynn, Conservative candidate for Jarrow 
A Foreign Office worker who lives in Surrey, Mr Gwynn says he voted Leave in the EU Referendum and will use his international experience to bring the “maximum benefit” to Jarrow in post-Brexit Britain. 
He says he has a history of campaigning on planning and housing issue, and will bring a “new perspective” to help increase access to employment and training. 
Mr Gwynn is also the chair of a charity which helps find employment for ex-offenders, and says he does not want vulnerable people to be overlooked. 
Liberal Democrat - Peter Maughan 
Solicitor Peter Maughan is running for the Liberal Democrats. 
He is a serving councillor in Gateshead, representing Dunston Hill and Whickham. 
Mr Maughan is a member of the Tyne and Wear fire authority. He lives in Whickham. 
He has worked for Browell Smith & Co and John Donkin solicitors. 
UKIP - James Askwith 
UKIP candidate James Askwith lives in Newcastle. 
ChronicleLive has contacted South Tyneside’s UKIP branch for more information about him. 
Green - David Herbert 
David Herbert, who lives in Cleadon, is standing for the Green Party. 
A former mining engineer and health and safety advisor, Mr Herbert has lived in South Tyneside all his life. He wants to see more funding for the NHS, and the railways re -nationalised. He also calls for a wealth tax to fund public services, free social care for the elderly, free nurseries for school children, improved public transport and more social housing. 
He is married to a retired teacher and has two daughters working for the NHS. Read More
